reviewText: Incorporated in 2004, QUALITY INFORMATION PUBLISHERS is an indie outfit based in Asheville, NC that sells dubs of public domain pictures but also specializes in rare and obscure movies and educational materials. They have an extensive online catalog, and a website that includes an 800 number and gmail addy. . After he dies in a plane crash in KILLERS FROM SPACE, Doug Martin (Peter Graves) is revived by extraterrestrials who hypnotize him into spying for them in advance of an all-out invasion. It's not apparent at first that this sci-fier is just another excuse for macro photography clips until Graves gets an injection of truth serum. In fact, except for a lone wall portrait of Ike Eisenhower that appears more often than your brother-in-law at dinnertime, everything here up to the needle seems quite stylish. Then a drugged Graves recounts his ludicrous story of aliens with ping pong ball eyes who plan to unleash their menagerie of giant bugs and lizards on an unsuspecting Earth, and everything goes right down the pipes. Boring stock film clips, overwrought acting and a faux-dramatic score make the story's second half laughably bad. After a chase scene in a 1950s power plant, we see through open venetian blinds that famous atomic bomb blast as the cast gathers on-camera and stares dumbfounded at its expanding mushroom cloud. But they're not silently contemplating the death of eyeball aliens or even humanity's imminent extinction. No, these disaffected thespians are all mentally resolving to dump their agents for saddllng them with this turkey. Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating. 2.9) Killers from Space (1954) - Peter Graves/James Seay/Steve Pendleton/Frank Gerstle/John Frederick/Barbara Bestar . FILM TRIVIA-- Directed by WILLIAM WILDER, the estranged older brother of Billy, whose real first name was Samuel. PETER GRAVES (Doug) also starred in the 'B' sci-fier RED PLANET MARS (1952). BARBARA BESTAR (Ellen Martin) was a dark-haired beauty who looked like an undernourished Liz Taylor. She primarily worked in TV westerns and dramas. Character actor JAMES SEAY (Col. Banks) gets impaled by an enormous hypodermic in THE AMAZING COLOSSAL MAN (1957). (VHS only)
